questions.text: A 8 year old boy has coryzal symptoms and a fever for the last 3 days. He has several circular erythematous lesions, with an area of pallor then central erythema. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
EM is characterized by an abrupt, symmetric cutaneous eruption, most commonly on the extensor upper extremities; appears initially as red macules or urticarial plaques that expand centrifugally to form lesions up to 2 cm in diameter with a dusky to necrotic center.

The pathogenesis of EM is unclear, but it may be a host-specific, cell-mediated immune response to an antigenic stimulus, resulting in damage to keratinocytes.

Etiology of erythema multiforme:

  • Herpes simplex virus
  • mycoplasma
  • Drug-related EM (<10% of patients) ~ nonsteroidal antiinflammatory agents, including acetaminophen, sulfonamides, and other antibiotics.

Treatment of EM is supportive.

Other options -

  • Option A. Erythema nodosum - A hypersensitivity reaction that usually appears as painful red bumps and bruises on the shins. It can also appear on the buttocks, calves, ankles, thighs, and arms. Erythema nodosum is often caused by a reaction to a medication, infection, or inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Option C. Erythema marginatum - A distinctive form of annular erythema that occurs on the trunk and the proximal extremities of patients with active rheumatic fever.
  • Option B. Erythema infectiosum - Also known as fifth disease, this childhood condition appears as a bright red rash on the cheeks, often giving the appearance of a slapped cheek. Other symptoms include fever, malaise, headache, vomiting, and diarrhea.

Topic: Exanthematous fevers

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 695, Page-4076

questions.text: Pheochromocytoma is a condition in which a benign tumor results in hypersecretion of the adrenal medulla. You will see all of the following symptoms except -
questions.solution:
Patients of pheochromocytoma have a good appetite but because of the hypermetabolic state may not gain weight, and severe cachexia may develop.

Other options -

  • Option A. Paroxysmal hypertension, results from excessive secretion of metanephrines, epinephrine and norepinephrine
  • Option B. Headache, palpitations, abdominal pain, and dizziness; pallor, vomiting, and sweating also occur.
  • Option D. Seizures and other manifestations of hypertensive encephalopathy may occur.

Topic: Adrenal disorders

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter-621, Page-3480

questions.text: 6-year-old female child was brought with history of recurrent bleeding per vaginal past 1 year, hyperpigmented patch at back and advanced bone age. There is no difficulty in vision and her breast development stage is Tanner stage 2. Most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
McCune-Albright syndrome is caused by a change in the GNAS1 gene, presenting with features of precocious puberty like (Tanner stage 2 breasts in a prepubertal child)with polyostotic fibrous dysplasia and abnormal pigmentation, is a syndrome of endocrine dysfunction associated with patchy cutaneous pigmentation and fibrous dysplasia of the skeletal system.

Other options -

  • Hypothalamic hamartomas - caused by developmental defect of the hypothalamus. Symptoms include seizures, precocious puberty, hormone imbalances, cognitive impairment, behavioral problems, and emotional difficulties.
  • Neurofibromatosis type 1 - characterized by multiple cafe au lait macules, intertriginous freckling, multiple cutaneous neurofibromas, and learning disability or behavior problems.
  • Tuberous sclerosis - caused by mutations in the TSC1 or TSC2 genes, which presents with facial angiofibromas, shagreen patches and other skin lesions, delayed development, learning difficulties, epilepsy, and autism.

Topic: Neurocutaneous syndromes

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter-600, Page-3392

questions.text: An infant is being evaluated at birth for clitoral hypertrophy. On investigations serum cortisol are low, ACTH is elevated, plasma renin activity is normal. There is increased 11 deoxycortisol level. Most likely enzyme deficient is
questions.solution:
11-hydroxylase deficiency

  • This type of CAH causes a buildup of precursors (11-deoxycortisol and deoxycorticosterone are elevated) that are converted to androgens leading to genital ambiguity in females and precocious puberty in both males and females.
  • Although cortisol is not synthesized efficiently, but mineralocorticoid like activity of Deoxycorticosterone can lead to hypertension and hypokalemia. Lack of cortisol leads to elevated ACTH.

Other options -

  • Option A. 21-hydroxylase deficiency - This is the most common type of CAH, accounting for 90-95% of cases. Symptoms include early pubic hair development, advanced bone age, and hirsutism in females, and early pubic hair development and growth acceleration in males.
  • Option C. 17-hydroxylase deficiency - Symptoms include hypertension, hypokalemia, and ambiguous or female external genitalia in males, and normal genitalia in females. Females with 17-hydroxylase deficiency may not develop breasts or menstruate in adolescence.
  • Option D. 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency - cause symptoms of both cortisol and aldosterone deficiency. Infants are prone to salt-wasting crisis. In females, symptoms include mild virilization and clitoromegaly in newborns

Extra edge: Causes of FEMALE-APPEARING GENITALIA: Clitoromegaly

  • XX with 21-or 11β-hydroxylase or 3β-hydroxy dehydrogenase deficiency
  • Other 46, XX DSD
  • Gonadal dysgenesis, dysgenetic testes, ovotesticular DSD
  • 46, XY DSD
  • Tumor infiltration of clitoris

Topic: Disorders of sexual development

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter-616, Page-3468

questions.text: Which of the following organism causes bullous impetigo?
questions.solution:
Bullous impetigo is always caused by Staphylococcus aureus strains that produce exfoliative toxins. The staphylococcal exfoliative toxins (ETA, ETB, ETD) blister the superficial epidermis by hydrolyzing human desmoglein 1, resulting in a subcorneal vesicle.

Other options -

  • Option B: Streptococcus pyogenes causes non-bullous Impetigo, Erysipelas and cellulitis
  • Option C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: A bacterium that can cause a variety of skin lesions, including:
    • Hot-tub rash: A dermatitis caused by a lack of proper water quality in hot tubs and swimming pools.
    • Swimmer's ear: A skin lesion caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
    • Ecthyma gangrenosum: A skin lesion associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • Diphtheroids: A skin lesion that appears as a vesicle or pustule that breaks down into a well-defined ulcer with an overhanging edge

Topic: Exanthematous fevers

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter-706, Page-4150

questions.text: Following disease presentation is caused by?
questions.solution:
• Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease): Benign, self-limited illness common in childhood.
  • Prodromal Phase:
    • Mild symptoms.
    • Low-grade fever (15-30% of cases).
    • Headache and mild upper respiratory tract infection.
  • Characteristic Rash:
    • Facial rash: Erythematous, "slapped-cheek" appearance.
    • Spread: Extends to trunk and proximal extremities as diffuse macular erythema.
    • Appearance: Lacy, reticulated due to central clearing of lesions.
  • Course:
    • Rash resolves spontaneously without peeling.
    • Waxing and waning over 1-3 weeks.
    • Can recur with sunlight, heat, exercise, and stress

Other options -

  • Option A. EBV can cause a variety of skin lesions, including maculopapular eruptions, which are flat areas of discoloration with small raised bumps.
  • Option D. Varicella causes an pruritic vesiculopapular rash that scab over. The rash usually starts on the chest, back, and face, and spreads to other parts of the body.
  • Option C. Scarlet fever causes a rash that starts as small, flat maculopaular. The rash can feel like sandpaper and looks like a bad sunburn. Other symptoms include a strawberry tongue, Pastia lines, and a period of desquamation after the rash begins to resolve.

Topic: Exanthematous Fevers

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 298, Page-1988

questions.text: The Fanconi syndrome is characterized by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Fanconi syndrome is a condition that's characterized by a defect in the proximal tubule of the kidney, which leads to the malabsorption of electrolytes and other substances leading to glycosuria, phosphaturia, bicarbonate wasting, and aminoaciduria. Other Symptoms include: Polyuria, Polydipsia, Dehydration associated with fever, Bone deformities and Muscle weakness.

Note: Fanconi syndrome is one of the causes of RTA type 2

Topic: Renal tubular disorders

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter-566, Page-3222

questions.text: The drug of choice for the following skin lesion with central clearing in a boy of 14 years of age is:
questions.solution:
This is Erythema migrans on the arm, showing central clearing/"bulls-eye" appearance in Lyme borreliosis.

Doxycyline is typically not used under the age of 12 due to risk of teeth staining.

Topic: Infectious diseases

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 268, Page-1885

questions.text: A 16 year old female presented to OPD with complaint of not having started menstruation. On examination - secondary sexual characters were compatible with her age, external genitalia was normal in appearance. On ultrasonography of whole abdomen, there was non visualisation of uterus along with partial absence of upper part of vagina, bilateral ovaries were normal in appearance. There was no abnormality of kidneys, liver, spleen and pancreas. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome (1 in 4,000 to 1 in 10,000 female births) is associated with: vaginal aplasia, uterine maldevelopment, and normal ovaries.

Type I MRKH - only mullerian aplasia occurs

Other options -

  • Option B. Type II MRKH - associated anomalies, most commonly unilateral renal agenesis or a horseshoe kidney, and skeletal anomalies are present in 10%
  • Option C. Zinner syndrome is considered the male counterpart of MRKH syndrome. In this condition, males with unilateral renal agenesis (or a regressed multicystic dysplastic kidney) have an ipsilateral seminal vesicle cyst, and a possible epididymal cyst and dilated distal ureteral segment. These patients typically present in adolescence.
  • Option D. Turner syndrome has streak ovaries

Topic: Disorders of sexual development

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter-574, Page-3260

questions.text: A 5 days old female newborn got admitted in NICU with acute intestinal obstruction due to duodenal atresia. She is receiving nasogastric decompression, maintenance intravenous fluid and electrolyte restoration. What is the first step in the investigation to rule out hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
• The initial step in the diagnosis of hyponatremia is the measurement of plasma osmolality.
  • The normal values of plasma osmolality are 275 to 290 milliosmoles per kilogram.
  • Plasma osmolality differentiates between hypertonic, isotonic and hypotonic hyponatremia.

Other options -

  • Option B. Volume Status - The next step in diagnosis is the evaluation of the volume status of extracellular fluid. Hyponatremia can be present with hypovolemia, hypervolemia, or euvolemia.
  • Option C. Urine Osmolality - Urine osmolality and sodium concentration are measured in patients with a lack of hypovolemic state and pseudo hyponatremia.
    • The urine osmolality < 100 milliosmoles/kg indicates - primary polydipsia.
    • The urine osmolality > 100 milliosmoles/kg indicates - high ADH concentration.
  • Option D. Urine Sodium Concentration - Differentiates between renal and extra renal causes of fluid loss in hypervolemic hyponatremia
    • If the sodium concentration in urine < 10 mmol/liter, it represents an extrarenal loss of fluids (vomiting and diuretic use). The kidneys retain sodium and preserve the normal homeostatic response to volume depletion. The non-renal causes of hypovolemic hyponatremia are differentiated based on the patient's history.
    • If the sodium concentration in urine is > 20 mmol/L, it indicates renal loss of fluids and the inability of the kidney to retain sodium. (salt-wasting nephropathies, vomiting, cortisol deficiency, and diuretics).

Fig. Flowchart for hyponatremia

Topic: Electrolyte disorders

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 73, Page 494

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with fever, cough, and tachypnea. The infant's parents report that the child has been feeding poorly and appears more irritable than usual. On examination, there is increased respiratory effort, nasal flaring, and bilateral wheezing on auscultation. Which viral pathogen is most likely responsible for this infant's viral pneumonia?
questions.solution:
RSV is a common cause of viral pneumonia in infants and young children, especially those under 1 year of age. It often presents with fever, cough, tachypnea, and increased respiratory effort.

Other options -

  • Option B. Influenza virus can also cause viral pneumonia but typically presents with more abrupt onset and high fever.
  • Option C. Human metapneumovirus is another viral pathogen that can cause pneumonia in children.
  • Option D. Adenovirus can cause respiratory illness but is less common in viral pneumonia compared to RSV.

Topic: Lower airway disorders

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd Edition, Chapter 449, Page 2643

questions.text: Which one of the following correctly matches regarding the trace elements deficiencies and their consequences?
questions.solution:
Zinc deficiency causes decreased growth, dermatitis of extremities and orifices, impaired immunity with poor healing, diarrhea and hypogonadism.

Other options -

  • Option B. Selenium deficiency causes cardiomyopathy and myopathy;
  • Option C. Fluoride deficiency causes dental caries.
  • Option D. Manganese deficiency causes hypercholesterolemia and weight loss;

Topic: Specific deficiencies

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 72, page 483

questions.text: In males, the first visible sign of puberty is testicular enlargement, beginning as early as
questions.solution:
In males, the first visible sign of puberty and the hallmark of SMR 2 is testicular enlargement, beginning as early as 9.5 yr, followed by the development of pubic hair.

Mnemonic: Testicular enlargementa → Pubarche, → Penile enlargementa → Growth spurt → Axillary and facial hair(Adrenarche)

This is followed by penile growth during SMR 3.

Peak growth occurs when testis volumes reach approximately 9-10 cm3 during SMR 4.

Under the influence of luteinizing hormone and testosterone, the seminiferous tubules, epididymis, seminal vesicles, and prostate enlarge. Sperm may be found in the urine by SMR 3; nocturnal emissions may be noted at this time as well.


Topic: Growth and development

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 150, page 1159

questions.text: Clinical manifestations of organophosphate toxicity relate to the accumulation of acetylcholine at peripheral nicotinic and muscarinic synapses and in the CNS. All the following are symptoms of cholinergic excess at muscarinic receptors EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Acute organophosphate toxicity is characterized by 3 phases:

  • Cholinergic crisis: The features of acute cholinergic crisis include diarrhea, urination, miosis, bronchorrhea/bronchospasm, bradycardia, emesis, lacrimation and salivation (DUMBBELS). Some patients show nicotinic features with hypertension, tachycardia and dysrhythmia, muscle weakness, fasciculations, tremors and hypoventilation.
  • Intermediate syndrome: While recovering from cholinergic crisis, some patients may develop respiratory failure (intermediate syndrome).
  • Delayed neuropathy: Late complications include delayed polyneuropathy and a range of chronic neuropsychiatric symptoms.

Topic: Poisoning

Reference: GHAI Essential Pediatrics, 10th edition, Chapter-28 , Page-755

questions.text: The laboratory work-up of a 2-day-old, healthy full-term male infant presenting with bleeding after circumcision reveals an isolated prolongation of activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) of 95 seconds. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, the isolated prolongation of aPTT suggests a deficiency in the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. Among the given options, the most likely diagnosis for a male infant with an isolated prolonged aPTT is Hemophilia A or Factor VIll deficiency, which is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by a deficiency in Factor VIII.

Other options -

  • Option B. Hemophilia B (Factor IX deficiency) is another common cause of isolated prolonged aPTT, however Hemophilia A is more commonly seen in males.
  • Option C. Factor XI deficiency is a less common cause of isolated prolonged aPTT compared to Hemophilia A and Hemophilia B.
  • Option D. Von Willebrand disease is a rare disorder, and although it can present with a prolonged aPTT due to low Factor VIll levels, It is less likely than Hemophilia A in a male infant with an isolated prolonged aPTT.

Therefore, in a male infant presenting with bleeding and an isolated prolonged aPTT, Hemophilia A (Factor VIII deficiency) is the most likely diagnosis.

Topic: Bleeding disorders

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter-525, Page-3029
